synopses.short_synopsis: Rhianna Dhillon reviews the Vincent van Gogh biopic At Eternity's Gate, BBC Two series Pose which is all about ball culture in eighties New York, and the return of Jane the Virgin on Netflix.

editorial_data.transcript: Hello music lover. On the podcast for you today, Rhianna Dhillon reviews the Vincent van Gogh biopic At Eternity's Gate, BBC Two series Pose - that's all about ball culture in eighties New York - and the return of Jane the Virgin on Netflix.
Plus, in The Maths of Life, Dr Hannah Fry breaks down the numbers behind coincidences and asks whether the perfect circle really does exist.
Film and TV critique, Rhianna Dhillon is already here and I have to be honest, we were already talking about Fleabag.
It's all we talk about. Omg!
Omg Rhianna! Fleabag!
It makes me so happy.
I know. I am getting so much fleabag joy. Yes! Happy sad. The Jolly Lad - beautiful ugly.
It's all of the... I believe 'hendiadys' is the technical term for those - not just a kind of contradiction but also appealing to more.
Loving fleabag! But you are here Rhianna, to give us your film and TV tips for this week. Should we start online?

synopses.short_synopsis: Rhianna reviews series five of this romantic comedy, available on Netflix

editorial_data.transcript: Let's start online with Jane the Virgin on Netflix which just makes me so happy. This is the return of Jane the Virgin. We are on series five now!
Five?
Yea. Its just started-
Well done Jane.
I know right? So the story so far with Jane the Virgin is, so it's all in the style - I don't know if you've have ever seen it - but it's all in the style of like Mexican telenovelas.
There's a voiceover, there are cliff-hangers at the end of every episode, there are sweeping romances.
Jane was a 23-year-old who wanted to wait until getting married and she ends up getting accidentally artificially inseminated by her boss, so ends up having virgin birth.
By her boss?

Yeah, yeah. And she is also sort of in this love triangle with this other lovely guy as well. And so there are these two men who really want her. She also has one of their babies and she still hasn't actually slept with either of them. Which I love! It's such a brilliant concept. So weird.
And so we come on to this on this massive cliff-hanger so - minor spoiler alert!
Okay.
But the end of the last series, Michael - who is Jane's husband by this point - died, and now appears possibly to have come back to life.
So this is all of us just going - oh my god!  Like screaming at the TV. It's so brilliant and soapy and stupid.
The religious metaphors don't sound like they're particularly light handed.
Oh no, absolutely not. This is very, very, very heavy.
But Jane is such a wonderful protagonist. She's played by Gina Rodriguez who was in Annihilation which was amazing, which you need to also check out if you haven't yet.

She is so likeable and determined. She's a great mother. She's a writer. She's very family-orientated. It's like the three matriarchs - her grandmother, her mother and her all in one house together. And just their love and their bond and their support for each other is just so - it's so brilliant to see that expressed on TV in this way.
You know, there are sort of really really positive female relationships and role models in her life, as much as it's about the guys in her life as well.

She has so much love to give - anything that goes right for her, ends up though going a little bit wrong at some point. So your heart is constantly breaking for her, but then you're always laughing always falling in love.
There's murder, there's intrigue, there are evil twins, like I said, coming back from the dead.
Sounds like a lot of fun!

Multiple times, kidnapping. It's so fun! And the outlandish-ness works because of the brilliant script. It's really tight and it is very very human as well. All of the characters are really well developed and like you know we're in series five now.

Every single one - even if at the beginning you sort of think one thing of them, they've gone on this incredible arc. You end up hating people at the beginning and then you have no choice but to fall in love with them by the end.
It just has the right amount of comedy and pathos and emotion and drama and I'm just really happy that it's back on our screens.
Jane the Virgin. I'm definitely adding this to my watchlist now, sounds absolutely phenomenal. What about on terrestrial TV? What have you got for us there?

synopses.short_synopsis: Rhianna reviews series five of this romantic comedy, available on Netflix
Rhianna reviews this BBC Two series about ball culture in eighties New York

editorial_data.transcript: So this is Pose. This is on BBC Two Thursdays at 9:00, but the whole box set is also on BBC iPlayer right now if you want to go and watch that.
It's from the creators of American Horror Story and Glee, who's Ryan Murphy and Brad Falchuk.

So, set in 1987 in New York, and is like this sort of cross-section of people from all over the city from different backgrounds, but it centres on Blanca who is a trans woman who starts her own house.
Oh, like ball culture house?

Yes, exactly. So she adopts misfits from around the city, who then take part in this underground ball scene where the LGBTQ community sort of compete against other houses, either by dressing up, dancing, performing, depending on the category.
There's a lot of voguing, which came from this movement. That's something I didn't know that's where voguing came from is from this movement, from a guy who invented it.

So this is the biggest trans cast of any program ever. It's so diverse. We see elements from so many different cultures, people finding their identities and working through their struggles of not being accepted.

But it's also - there's so much positivity in there. It's all about finding your family who will love and protect you, even if they're not blood relatives. And how this LGBTQ community created this space for themselves where nobody else really wanted them.
And the flip side of it is - this is set against the economic boom of the 80s.

So you've got someone like this actor, Evan Peters who's made loads of these. He's done American Horror Story with Ryan Murphy before, he was Quicksilver in X-Men so he plays a guy who's just been... got work in Trump Towers.

So there's always kind of quite on-the-nose comments about how Trump is "Oh I can't believe he's so rich. Oh my God! I admire him so much" which is really interesting now compared, obviously, to our current situation.
But there is just so much love and tenderness for this scene. It's a bit manic. It's a bit OTT.
The soundtrack's presumably amazing. I'm just - you know, I mean there's a lot to pick from there.
Of course. But I just love that it is shining a spotlight on something that we might think is a hot topic now, but actually has been going on for over 30 years and we're just playing catch-up.
And we're heading to the cinema, Rhianna. What are we going to watch?
Yes we are. So this is something a little bit different.

synopses.short_synopsis: Rhianna reviews this BBC Two series about ball culture in eighties New York
Rhianna reviews this Vincent van Gogh biopic, in cinemas now

external_link.caption: IMDb page for At Eternity's Gate

editorial_data.transcript: At Eternity's Gate. This is a sort of loose biopic about the last few years of Vincent van Gough's life told, quite aptly, in a very artistic, unusual way and it focuses on his mental health, his relationship with Paul Gauguin - which was the catalyst to him cutting off a bit of his ear - and how no one rated him, although he was a good painter, and society's basic rejection of him and how he coped with that.
Not very well.
So it stars Willem Dafoe and Oscar Isaac. It should not work that Dafoe is playing Vincent van Gogh who was only 37 when he died.
Yeah, right.
Willem Dafoe is older.
But I mean he could play anything.
He can!
He's not a Green Hornet or whatever it was, is he? But, you know, he did that quite well.

image.caption: Willem Dafoe as The Green Goblin

editorial_data.transcript: Haha! I enjoyed that role actually. It's brilliant - the Green Goblin.
Yeah, the Green Goblin.
He's very good at that. He's very good at being evil. But in this, he is a very sympathetic Van Gough.

And I really love that this gave us of time with him. You know, time to breathe with him, time to just follow his - it's not even mania. There are moments where he's just running through fields and then stops to paint in the light.
And because you've spent that time with him, just in silence, but just watching him do this, you sort of appreciate what his methods were.
And yeah, I really, really, really enjoyed seeing Willem Dafoe playing something a little bit different, more interesting more thoughtful.

I think we're so used to Van Gough's art as well, aren't we. You know, the images have become so iconic and they're so every day that actually to be able to see them with fresh eyes is really interesting.

I enjoyed Loving Vincent which was a couple of years ago, another film about him and that was all done - it was the first film full-length feature that had ever been painted. Every frame was painted over, wasn't it.
Yes, it was very swirly.
Yes. It was - I mean if you'd had a couple and perhaps been on a revolving dance floor and the tuxedo princesses I have in my youth, you wouldn't want to watch it then, but it was enjoyable.
Is this coming from a similar kind of place? You know, are we seeing the world through his eyes?

Yes, because the style is very unique and weird, and it doesn't always work actually. But I really like that it takes risks because a film like this could have been quite pedestrian. A lot of biopics can be very pedestrian and safe.
There's a lot of breaking the fourth wall, talking to the camera, layering images and sounds over each other to create confusion, and to show how he really obsessed over things and over people.
So, when Oscar Isaac comes in as Gauguin, you can absolutely see the pool and the charisma that this guy has over him, and his arrogance and his sort of-
Rock-n-roller, wasn't he?
Yeah he was! He was so impetuous and he was trying to tell Van Gough how to paint and what he was doing wrong, and you just get so frustrated with it.
Stop doing sunflowers! Come to Polynesia, that kind of thing. Honestly!
Oh my God, I did my French A-levels speaking on Gauguin. I don't know why I thought it'd be fun. It was not fun. Finding out more about Gauguin life is really horrible. I don't recommend it.
Well, some threads you don't want to pull.
Thank you very much, Rhianna Dillon. This week's watch list.

Just to recap, we've got Pose for you on the BBC iPlayer box set. That's your TV selection. At Eternity's Gate at the cinema, and on Netflix for streaming series five of Jane the Virgin. Thank you so much.
Thank you.
Cheers.

synopses.short_synopsis: Rhianna reviews this Vincent van Gogh biopic, in cinemas now
